name: Mercury
description: The smallest, fastest and also the planet that is closest to the sun. The surface of Mercury is covered in tens of thousands of impact craters. Mercury is also the fastest planet, zipping around the Sun every 88 Earth days.

event.name: Landing on the surface of Mercury
event.description: 77 Million kilometers is not a short distance. But we promise it will be worth it. You'll get a view of the Sun unlike anywhere else in the Solar System.

event.name: Hiking on the hot peaks of Mercury
event.description: After you get some proper rest and cool down a bit from the long traveling we are going on hiking! The Caloris Montes are the ring of mountainous peaks that make up the rim of the Caloris basin. This linear hills and valleys extend more than 1000km. You can see the southeastern portion of the rim on the image below.

event.name: Leaving the planet
event.description: Your one day expidition ends with the exhausting hiking and it's time to take our leave.

name: Venus
description: The Earth's twin but with a surface hot enough to melt lead. With thick atmosphere, this planet holds its name for a love goddess.

event.name: Landing on the surface of Venus
event.description: Good job on landing, but get some rest in the hibernation chambers. We've got quite some time to kill before our activities.

event.name: Expedition in Ishtar Terra - Climbing on the Maxwell Montes
event.description: Maxwell Montes is a mountain massif on the planet Venus. We'll be climbing to it's peak, Skadi Mons, which is the highest point on the planet's surface. Located on Ishtar Terra, the more northern of the planet's two major highlands, Maxwell Montes is 11 kilometreshigh. It rises about 6.4 kilometers above and to the east of Lakshmi Planum which will be visiting later, and is about 853 kilometres long by 700 kilometres wide. The western slopes are very steep, whereas the eastern slopes descend gradually into Fortuna Tessera. Due to its elevation, it is the coolest and least pressurised location on the surface of Venus.

event.name: Expedition in Ishtar Terra - Touring the Lakshmi Planum
event.description: Lakshmi Planum is a plateau feature approximately 2 million sq km ringed by rugged mountains, the surface of Venus on the Western Ishtar Terra. It is named after Lakshmi, the Hindu goddess of wealth. It is roughly 3.5 to 5 kilometers above the mean planetary radius. Lakshmi Planum is ringed by intensely deformed terrain and it's plains are made up of radar-dark, homogeneous, smooth lava flows. You can take a rest in hibernation chamber now, we have some time before the next expedition in Aphrodite Terra.

event.name: Expedition in Aphrodite Terra
event.description: Located near the equator of Venus, Aphrodite Terra has an area about half the size of Africa, and is much larger than the rougher Ishtar Terra. It is covered with deep rift valleys. Like Ishtar Terra, Aphrodite Terra also has mountain ranges but they are only about half the size of the mountains on Ishtar. Extending nearly two thirds around the planet, Aphrodite Terra's topography appears buckled and fractured which suggests large compressive forces. There are also numerous extensive lava flows across this terrain and some have an interesting bow shape to them due to atmospheric gravity waves. You can take another quick hibernation before our final expedition in Lada Terra

event.name: Expedition in Lada Terra
event.description: Lada Terra is a major landmass near the south pole of Venus which is centered at 60°S and 20°E and has a diameter of 8,615 kilometres. The broad region of Lada Terra contains massive coronae, rift zones, and volcanic plains as well as many other features that scientists use to attempt to piece together the history of this complex planet. The distinctive cross-cutting relationships found in the bedding of Lada Terra have been important in realizing relative ages of the extensional belts and coronae, as well as the complex tesserae features present planet-wide.

event.name: Leaving the Planet
event.description: We didn't even spend a day, but 2/3 of a year on Venus and it's time to go home. Hopefully you enjoyed the expeditions in the three highlands of Venus.

name: Mars
description: Mars is no place for  the faint - hearted. It's dry, rocky and bitter cold. The fourth planet from the Sun and the easiest one to spot in the night sky - it looks like a bright red point of light.

event.name: Landing on the surface of Mars
event.description: At first glance, Mars appears very different from Earth, but if you take a closer look, you'll discover that the Red Planet isn't all that different from our own.

event.name: Visiting the North Pole
event.description: Our first stop, the North Pole. This ice cap is bigger than Texas, and is mostly covered in water ice and solid carbon dioxide, aka dry ice. Heading south, we'll visit Kasei Valles. It's a vast system of chasms five times longer and 10 times wider than the Grand Canyon, and scientists think it formed in a similar way. Billions of years ago, Mars was warmer, and covered with liquid water, which likely carved out valleys like this one.

event.name: Decending to Mawrth Vallis
event.description: Mawrth Vallis is another valley close by, but it looks very different from our previous spot, thanks to its multicolored layers of clay. These deposits probably formed over millennia as Mars shifted towards a colder, drier climate, and they could provide clues to the history of liquid water and possible ancient life on Mars.

event.name: Exploring Inside the Bacquerel Crater
event.description: The next stop is another place that may have been teeming with life long ago, Bacquerel Crater. It's filled with rocks made of sulfate similar to ones on Earth that form after water evaporates, which has led scientists to suspect that this crater may once have been a massive lake over 160 kilometers wide.

event.name: Traversing Iani Chaos
event.description: Next stop, Iani Chaos. Now, this is one type of terrain you won't find anywhere on Earth. It's a maze of rugged cliffs and pillar-like hills called mesas that extend for 200 kilometers, and since there is nothing like it on Earth, scientists aren't exactly sure how these unique features formed. Its larger neighbor, Hydraotes Chaos, probably formed in a similar mysterious way. It stretches 350 kilometers, the same distance as New York City to Boston.

event.name: Expedition to Valles Marineris
event.description: Valles Marineris, or Mariner Valley, is a vast canyon system that runs along the Martian equator just east of the Tharsis region. Valles Marineris is 4000 km long and reaches depths of up to 7 km! For comparison, the Grand Canyon in Arizona is about 800 km long and 1.6 km deep.

event.name: Exploring the Hebes Chasma
event.description: Hebes Chasma is an isolated chasma just north of the Valles Marineris canyon system of Mars. It is centered at 1 degree southern latitude and 76 degrees western longitude, just between the Martian equator and the Valles Marineris system, just east of the Tharsis region.

event.name: Sighseeing at Hellas Plantina
event.description: With a diameter of about 1,400 miles and a depth reaching the lowest elevations on Mars, Hellas is one of the largest impact craters in the solar system. The area has a number of unusual features, which are thought to be quite old because of the high crater density. The crater inside Hellas has been filled with material, which may be related to volcanic activity on the basin’s northwestern rim. It also might be related to the presence water and water ice. However, there is evidence elsewhere that the ground here is rich with ice.

event.name: Exploring Curiosity's Landing Site - Gale Crater
event.description: The Curiosity rover landed at the foot of a layered mountain within this massive crater. The portion of the crater where Curiosity landed has an alluvial fan likely formed by water-carried sediments. The layers at the base of the mountain contain clays and sulfates, both known to form in water. Curiosity will go beyond the follow-the-water strategy of recent Mars exploration. Gale Crater formed when a meteor hit Mars in its early history, about 3.5 to 3.8 billion years ago. The meteor impact punched a hole in the terrain. The explosion ejected rocks and soil that landed around the crater. Scientists chose Gale Crater as the landing site for Curiosity because it has many signs that water was present over its history. Water is a key ingredient of life as we know it.

event.name: Final Expedition to the South Pole
event.description: Finally, we've reached our last stop, the South Pole. In 2018, scientists found evidence of a liquid lake beneath the ice, which could be filled with saltwater. But while that's a promising discovery, we still have much to learn about this fascinating world, like whether life once existed in those ancient lakes, or if it still exists today, possibly somewhere underground.

event.name: Leaving the Planet
event.description: This concludes our tour of Mars. It was a long journey from the North all the way to the South Pole. You got to explore a lot of places and now just before the end of the day we're taking our leave.

name: Jupiter
description: Jupiter is named for the king of the ancient Roman gods. It is by far the largest planet in the solar system. Jupiter's stripes and swirls are actually cold, windy clouds of ammonia and water, floating in an atmosphere of hydrogen and helium.

event.name: Landing on the surface of Jupiter
event.description: We just landend on the magnificent giant of our solar system.

event.name: Witnessing Volcanic Eruptions on Io
event.description: Jupiter's moon Io is the most volcanically active world in the Solar System, with hundreds of volcanoes, some erupting lava fountains dozens of miles (or kilometers) high. Io is caught in a tug-of-war between Jupiter's massive gravity and the smaller but precisely timed pulls from two neighboring moons that orbit farther from Jupiter—Europa and Ganymede. Io's volcanoes are at times so powerful that they are seen with large telescopes on Earth, and Io even has lakes of molten silicate lava on its surface. Only slightly larger than Earth's Moon, Io is about one-quarter the diameter of Earth itself.

event.name: Seeing Jupiter's Auroras
event.description: The auroras are brilliant curtains of light in Jupiter's upper atmosphere. Jovian auroral storms, like Earth's, develop when electrically charged particles trapped in the magnetic field surrounding the planet spiral inward at high energies toward the north and south magnetic poles. When these particles hit the upper atmosphere, they excite atoms and molecules there, causing them to glow.

event.name: Traveling to the Great Red Spot
event.description: The Great Red Spot is a persistent high-pressure region in the atmosphere of Jupiter, producing an anticyclonic storm that is the largest in the Solar System. It is the most recognizable feature on Jupiter, owing to its red-orange color whose origin is still unknown. It has been swirling wildly over Jupiter's skies for the past 150 years—maybe even much longer than that. And today you will have the chance to expirience it!

event.name: Leaving the Surface of Jupiter
event.description: At midnight we leave after a long journey around the massive gas giant.

name: Saturn
description: A massive ball made mostly of hydrogen and helium. The presence of icy rings makes this planet unique. This is also the farthest planet discovered by naked eye.

event.name: Saturn's Rings
event.description: Saturn is a planet made of gas and doesn't have a true surface. So we can't land on it. But that doesn't mean we can't marvel at the majestic rings encircling Satur through the mirrors of our spaceship!

event.name: Exploring Titan: Saturn's largest moon
event.description: As we descend to the surface of Saturn's largest moon Titan you'll see an extraordinary and exceptional world. Among our Solar System's more than 150 known moons, Titan is the only one with a substantial atmosphere. And of all the places in the solar system, Titan is the only place besides Earth known to have liquids in the form of rivers, lakes and seas on its surface.

event.name: Leaving the Atmospere
event.description: We head our way back home but you can still enjoy the other moons that Saturn has, through the windows of the spaceship.

name: Uranus
description: Cold and windy planet, surrounded by many moons and few rings. The large amounts of methane makes this planet blue - green in color.

event.name: Approaching the Atmosphere of Uranus
event.description: Uranus is an ice giant, the planet is mostly swirling fluids. This makes it impossible to land on Uranus. So this tour we'll be focusing on Uranus's mesmerizing atmosphere and it's moons.

event.name: Observing the moons of Uranus - Miranda
event.description: Miranda is known for its diverse and chaotic terrain. Its surface has a features like: deep canyons, cliffs, and some unique terrains and formations. Miranda contrasts from smooth to fractured landscapes.

event.name: Observing the moons of Uranus - Oberon
event.description: The second largest moon orbiting Uranus, Oberon has a heavily cratered surface. Enjoy the beauty of its icy plains and interesting terrains, also the impact craters.

event.name: Leaving the Atmosphere
event.description: Hope you enjoyed distanced view of Uranus and it's moons. Even tho we couldn't step foot on it ourselfs we still got a good look of the ice giant.

name: Neptune
description: The most distant planet orbiting the Sun. Big, Dark and Cold, Neptune can not be seen by a naked human eye.

event.name: Appraching Neptune
event.description: Neptune is one of the planets made out of gas so we can't really land on it. But, just like with Uranus that doesn't stop us from exploring the moons and the atmosphere.

event.name: Seeing Neptune's Wicked Weather
event.description: Neptune's dark vortices are high-pressure systems that can form at mid-latitudes and may then migrate toward the equator. They start out remaining stable due to Coriolis forces, which cause northern hemisphere storms to rotate clockwise, due to the planet's rotation. These storms are unlike hurricanes on Earth, which rotate counterclockwise because they are low-pressure systems. However, as a storm drifts toward the equator, the Coriolis effect weakens and the storm disintegrates.

event.name: Exploring Neptune's moons - Triton
event.description: An interesting fact about Triton is that it orbits Neptune in the opposite direction of the planet's rotation. Triton is also Neptune's biggest moon, featuring diverse terrain, icy plains, mountains and geysers.

event.name: Exploring Neptune's moons - Proteus
event.description: Proteus has a heacily cratered surface, making it one of the most irreguraly shaped moons. That also makes some fascinating landscapes on this moon.

event.name: Leaving the Atmosphere
event.description: Hope you enjoyed distanced view of Neptune and it's moons. Even tho we couldn't step foot on it ourselfs we still got a good look of the furthest planet in our Solar System.
